page.title: 01Wildmore Fen, Lincolnshire
page.content: Stand at any point within this area and one has an uninterupted view of a flat landscape, dotted here and there with houses and crossed at frequent intervals by ditches and dykes, connecting with larger drains. Land drainage is of vital importance as some areas are no more than one metre above sea level. Maintenance of the drains, for which landowners and householders pay an annual rate, is carried out by a Drainage Board. Agriculture is predominant here. Apart from one dairy farm of 240 acres, the heavy soil type lends itself best to growing winter sown cereals, with sugar beet, oil seed rape and a small acreage of potatoes and other brassicas grown as break crops. There is a hamlet at Bunkers Hill, otherwise the population of 170 scattered, most having some connection
